questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is an 'Anti-infective' vitamin?
questions.explanation:
Vitamin A is required for the maintenance of epithelial functions, creating an effective barrier 
against pathogens; hence, it is called as an anti-infective vitamin. So, vitamin A deficiency can 
lead to changes in the epithelia of all mucosal surfaces, leading to increased chances of infections. Vitamin E (Tocopherol) helps is an anti-oxidant. Deficiency manifests as skin changes and hair 
loss. Vitamin D maintains calcium and phosphorus homeostasis. Deficiency can lead to rickets in 
children and osteomalacia in adults. Vitamin C helps in the formation of connective tissues and collagen in the skin, bone, and blood 
vessels. Deficiency leads to their fragility and causes scurvy. 139 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 2: What would be the ideal dose of vitamin - A that you should prescribe to a 9-month-old infant 
along with the measles vaccine?
questions.explanation: For a child aged 9 months, the dose of vitamin A given is 100,000 IU.

questions.question:
Question 3: A 2-year-old unvaccinated girl is brought to the OPD with high-grade fever and 
maculopapular rashes for 2 days. On examination, she has blue-white spots on her buccal 
mucosa as shown in the image attached below. Which of the following vitamin deficiency is 
associated with this condition? 131 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The girl is suffering from measles. It is associated with vitamin A deficiency. Vitamin A deficiency is associated with an increased risk of infection and increased mortality with 
a variety of infectious diseases particularly measles. Hence, vitamin A therapy is indicated in all 
patients with measles. The main functions of vitamin A are as follows: • Maintenance of vision, especially night vision • Maintenance of epithelial tissues • Differentiation of various tissues, particularly during reproduction and gestation, by regulating 
gene expression. Features of vitamin A deficiency: • Eyes: Defective dark adaptation is a characteristic early clinical feature, resulting in night 
blindness (earliest manifestation). This can further progress to xerophthalmia, Bitot's spots, 
conjunctivitis, or keratomalacia, leading to blindness. • Poor overall growth, anaemia • Diarrhoea, susceptibility to infections • Increased intracranial pressure • Keratinization of mucous membranes and skin (hyperkeratosis)

questions.question:
Question 4: A young girl of class 4 complains of a burning sensation in the eye. Clinical examination of 
eyes reveals the finding shown below. What could be the mechanism for the development of 
such lesions?

options.a: Deposition of calcium in the conjunctiva

questions.explanation:
The given clinical image is showing Bitot spots, which occur due to keratinization of the 
conjunctival epithelium. Bitot spots are triangular, frequently bilateral, and present on the bulbar 
conjunctiva. Normally, bulbar conjunctiva is a stratified, columnar, non-keratinized epithelium. In vitamin A 
deficiency, there is squamous metaplasia of the conjunctival epithelium and tangles of keratin 
admixed with gas-forming bacteria producing a dry, scaly patch with a foamy appearance called 
Bitot spots. Option A: Deposition of calcium in the conjunctiva is termed conjunctival concretions, which 
usually occurs over the palpebral conjunctiva, in chronic inflammatory conditions of the eye. Option B: Scarring of the conjunctiva is seen in chlamydial infection of the eye. Option C: Excessive growth of conjunctival tissue is seen in the pterygium of the eye. 140 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 5: A 6-year-old boy with complaints of dry, itchy eyes and night blindness had the following 
ophthalmic finding as given in the image. What is the stage of vitamin A deficiency as per 
WHO classification?
questions.explanation:
The image depicts a corneal ulcer occupying <1/3rd of the cornea under a slit lamp with a 
fluorescein stain. This corresponds to stage X3A of vitamin A deficiency.

questions.question:
Question 6: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the OPD with complaints of headache, desquamation of the 
skin, and bone pain. Pathological examination revealed lysosomal rupture within the cells, 
prompting a suspicion of hypervitaminosis A. Which of the following statement is false about 
the principle vitamin that is excess in the given condition?
questions.explanation:
Both hypervitaminosis A and deficiency of vitamin A cause raised intracranial pressure (ICP) (not 
just hypervitaminosis A). 11-cis retinal(not trans) is required for vision. Hypervitaminosis A causes headache, vomiting, desquamation of the skin, and hyperostosis of 
long bones. Rupture of lysosomes in the cells is the pathological feature of hypervitaminosis A. All-trans retinoic acid is the most bioactive form of vitamin A, and it is required for cell 
differentiation and the regulation of transcription. On the other hand, 11-cis retinal is required for 
vision. Protein-energy malnutrition can cause vitamin A deficiency because of the impaired 
synthesis of retinol-binding protein (RBP).

questions.question:
Question 7: Your best friend is recently worried that she has a lot of hair fall. Which of the following 
vitamin capsules if added to her diet can help prevent free radical injury and thus be 
beneficial for her??
questions.explanation:
Vitamin E/ Tocopherol is a potent antioxidant and is helpful in preventing hair fall. It promotes 
hair growth and prevents hair roots from getting damaged by free radical injury. Alpha-tocopherol is the active component of vitamin E and it is mainly located within cell 
membranes, preventing lipid peroxidation and the formation of free radicals. Deficiency of this can also lead to neurological defects, hemolysis, and posterior column defect. Treatment includes vitamin E supplementation (25–50 units/day for a week). Note: The other vitamins having antioxidant properties are vitamins A, C, and E (vitamin E is the most 
important). The other vitamin beneficial in the treatment of hair fall is biotin.

questions.question:
Question 8: An anxious mother brings her 6-month-old child with concerns about not gaining weight and 
height. On examination, stunted growth, craniotabes, frontal bossing, and craniosynostosis 
are noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Craniotabes (soft skull), frontal bossing, stunted growth, and craniosynostosis are clinical features 
of rickets. General features include failure to thrive, listlessness, protruding abdomen, proximal muscle 
weakness, and fractures. Head to toe-examination would include the following features: 141 
Sold by @itachibot Head examination would include craniotabes, frontal bossing, delayed fontanel closure, delayed 
dentition, and craniosynostosis. Chest examination would reveal rachitic rosary, Harrison's sulcus, and repeated respiratory 
infections and atelectasis. Spinal deformities could include kyphosis, scoliosis, lordosis. Limb examination and extremities may show windswept deformity, anterior bowing of tibia, coxa 
vara, and enlargement of wrists and ankles. Bowings of legs (genu varum) or knock knees (genu 
valgum) may be noted. These changes can be seen only in children of the weight-bearing age 
group/ toddlers. The image shows frontal bossing: The image below shows the rachitic rosary: The image below shows craniotabes: 142 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 9: The X-ray image of a child with muscle weakness and failure to thrive is attached below. 
What is the likely diagnosis? 134 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The clinical vignette with the above X-ray image shows fraying and cupping of the metaphysis, 
suggestive of rickets. Radiological features in rickets: • Fraying (Widening and irregularity of the growth plate) • Cupping (Concavity of the metaphysis) • Splaying at metaphysis (widening of metaphyseal ends) • Generalized rarefaction

questions.question:
Question 10: An 8-year-old child from a rural slum area is brought to your OPD with deformity as shown in 
the image. Which of the following conditions is characteristically associated with this 
deformity?
questions.explanation:
Windswept deformity (combination of valgus deformity of one leg with varus deformity of the 
other leg) is seen in rickets. It is also seen in rheumatoid arthritis but characteristically seen in 
rickets. Other deformities of extremities seen in rickets: • Enlargement of wrists and ankles • Valgus or varus deformities of limbs • Anterior bowing of the tibia and femur • Coxa vara 143 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: Your school friend brings his 5-year-old son to your OPD with small swellings on the chest 
that he had felt while giving the child a bath. On examination, you note swellings at the 
costochondral junctions. Which of the following conditions would be your differentials to this 
clinical presentation?
questions.explanation:
Swelling of the costochondral junctions is seen in all the 3 conditions mentioned above. Rachitic rosary 
Scorbutic rosary Angulated in appearance Beaded (rounded) in appeara 
nce Non-tender 
Tenderness on palpation (sub 
periosteal haemorrhage) Due to metaphyseal widening 
Due to epiphyseal separation Note: Tietze syndrome is the benign inflammation of the costochondral junction. Image: Given below is a photo of the chest cage with pectus excavatum. 144 
Sold by @itachibot Image: The above image shows a rachitic rosary type of appearance.

questions.question:
Question 12: A 22-month-old girl presents with failure to thrive and delayed achievement of motor 
milestones. On examination, she seems irritable and is noted to have bowed legs, thick wrists, 
and dental caries. Which of the following is not a radiographic sign of this condition?

options.a: Increase in the width of the growth plate

questions.explanation:
The child is suffering from rickets. Subperiosteal hemorrhage is not a radiographic sign of rickets. 
On the contrary, it is seen in scurvy. Radiographic features of rickets: • Widening of the growth plate: Decreased calcification leads to reduced bone density • Fraying: The edge of the metaphysis loses its sharp border. • Cupping: The edge of the metaphysis changes from a convex or flat surface to a more concave 
surface. • Splaying: Weight-bearing and stress on the uncalcified bone gives rise to the widening of the 
metaphyseal end. • Enlargement of the wrists and ankles due to the widening of the distal end of the metaphysis. • Coarse trabeculation of the diaphysis • Generalized rarefaction

questions.question:
Question 13: A 2-year-old child from an urban slum is diagnosed with nutritional rickets. Which of the 
following biochemical markers can be seen in this child?
questions.explanation:
In nutritional rickets serum, alkaline phosphatase levels are increased. Biochemical findings in nutritional rickets (nutritional vitamin D deficiency): • Normal or low calcium (since due to low calcium and vitamin D deficiency, PTH increases which 
will try to normalize the low calcium) 145 
Sold by @itachibot • Parathyroid hormone levels are elevated (in order to increase the serum calcium) • Hypophosphatemia (because of increased parathyroid hormone [PTH]) • Metabolic acidosis (secondary to PTH induced renal bicarbonate wasting)

questions.question:
Question 14: A child in your unit is admitted with alopecia, oligodontia, and features of rickets with 
elevated serum levels of alkaline phosphatase activity and 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D. What 
could be the pathology?
questions.explanation:
Alopecia and oligodontia (reduced number of teeth) with features of rickets in a child is classically 
seen in vitamin D-dependant rickets type 2 where the pathology is end-organ resistance (receptor 
hyposensitivity) to vitamin D. Rickets causes • Nutritional vitamin D deficiency • Secondary vitamin D deficiency • Vitamin D-dependant rickets, type 1 (defect in 1-alpha hydroxylase) • Vitamin D-dependant rickets, type 2 (end organ resistance) • Chronic kidney disease • Hypophosphatemic rickets • X-linked dominant hypophosphatemic rickets (PHEX gene mutation) • Autosomal dominant (fibroblast growth factor [FGF] resistance to endopeptidases) • Oncogenous rickets (increased FGF 23) Note: Vitamin D antibodies are found in most patients of systemic sclerosis.

questions.question: Question 15: Stoss therapy is used in the treatment of which of the following micronutrient deficiencies?
questions.explanation:
Stoss therapy is used in the treatment of vitamin D deficiency. There are 2 strategies for the administration of vitamin D: • Stoss therapy: Here, 300,000-600,000 IU of vitamin D are administered orally or 
intramuscularly as 2 or 4 doses over 1 day. • The alternative strategy is daily vitamin D with a minimum dose of 2,000 IU/day for a minimum 
of 3 months. Both strategies should be followed by a daily vitamin D intake of 400 IU/day if the child is < 
1-year-old or 600 IU/day if the child is >1-year-old. Children must also receive adequate dietary 
calcium and phosphorus. 146 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 16: A child with rickets not responding to treatment is being evaluated. Investigations show 
serum calcium level of 9 mg/dL, low phosphate level of 2 mg/dL, elevated alkaline 
phosphatase, and normal parathyroid hormone levels with normal arterial blood gas levels. 
What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario of a child with a history of treatment-resistant rickets, normal levels of 
calcium (9 to 11 mg/dL), parathyroid hormone, arterial blood gas (ABG), with decreased 
phosphate (normal, 2.5 to 4.3 mg/dL), and elevated levels of alkaline phosphatase (normal, 33 to 
96 U/L) is suggestive of hypophosphatemic rickets. Hypophosphatemic rickets: X- linked dominant hypophosphatemic rickets is the most common genetic cause of rickets while 
the most common, overall is nutritional vitamin D 
deficiency. PHEX gene (phosphate-regulating endopeptidase on x chromosome) products are 
responsible for the inactivation of phosphatonin. Mutation of this PHEX leads to increased 
phosphatonin (FGF 23) levels, and hence, the excretion of phosphorous is increased. This is also 
associated with impaired renal tubular reabsorption of phosphate leading to its excess excretion. The chart attached below summarizes the evaluation of hypophosphatemic rickets. Treatment-resistant rickets : Patients respond well to a combination of oral phosphorus and 1,25-D (calcitriol). Frequent dosing 
helps prevent prolonged decrements in serum phosphorus levels because there is a rapid decline 
after each dose. In addition, frequent dosing decreases diarrhea, which is a complication of 
high-dose oral phosphorus.

questions.question:
Question 17: A concerned mother of an infant, known case of cystic fibrosis, presents to your OPD with 
complaints of abdominal pain, loose stools not settling with antibiotics, and other 
medications. She recently stopped breastfeeding and switched to formula feeds. On 
examination, you find petechial rashes. Which of the following below mentioned causes 137 
Sold by @itachibot would not prompt you to suspect a deficiency of Vitamin K in this child?
questions.explanation:
Vitamin K deficiency occurs mostly in breastfed infants not in artificial milk-fed babies, as the 
formula milk is fortified. The use of broad-spectrum antibiotics that eliminate the intestinal vitamin K2- producing 
bacteria can cause vitamin K deficiency. Biliary atresia causes malabsorption of vitamin K, due to 
defective fat absorption. 147 
Sold by @itachibot There are 3 forms of vitamin K deficiency bleeding (VKDB) of the newborn: Early VKBD of the newborn is prevented by the administration of a single intramuscular (IM) 
injection of vitamin K (1 mg) at birth. Early VKDB(classic hemorrh

and interferes with Vit K fun

rth, poor transfer of Vitamin

questions.question: Question 18: What is the recommended dietary allowance (RDA) of vitamin D in a 4-year-old child?
questions.explanation: In a child of age 4 years, the recommended dietary allowance (RDA) of vitamin D is 600 IU. Note: • Vitamin A: 1 IU = 1 IU retinol = 0.3 mcg of Retinol Equivalents (RE) • Vitamin C: 1 IU = 50 mcg of ascorbic acid • Vitamin D: 1 IU = 0.025 mcg cholecalciferol

questions.question: Question 19: Rickets in an infant presents as all except
questions.explanation:
Bowing of legs is not a feature of rickets in infants, because it appears only after weight-bearing. 
Thus, bow legs are a feature of rickets in toddlers. Image: Rachitic rosary (widening of the costochondral junctions) 148 
Sold by @itachibot Image: Wrist X-ray image

questions.question: Question 20: Which of the following is false regarding phosphatonins?
questions.explanation:
Phosphatonin is a group of phosphate-regulating factors produced by osteocytes, and FGF 23 is 
the most important phosphatonin. Phosphatonin increases renal excretion (not reabsorption) of 
phosphate. Mechanism of phosphatonin action: Vitamin D receptor activation by 1,25 dihydroxy D (active vit D)  FGF 23 release by osteocytes 149 
Sold by @itachibot  Reduces expression of sodium-phosphate transporter in proximal convoluted tubules of the 
kidney  Increased urinary phosphate excretion Meanwhile, phosphatonin decreases the activity of 1 alpha hydroxylase and, therefore, the 
production of 1,25-D as well. So, the absorption of phosphate from the intestine is also reduced. 150 
Sold by @itachibot Deficiency of Water-soluble Vitamins & Trace Elements
